pubinfo.publish: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

descript.abstract: The North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section in cooperation with the NC Center for Geographic Information and Analysis, has developed the geographic data to provide accurate location of public water supply system sources in North Carolina.
descript.purpose: These data were created for North Carolina's Source Water Assessment Program and to assist governmental agencies and others in making resource management decisions through use of a Geographic Information System (GIS).

place.placekt: William S. Powell, The North Carolina GAZETTEER, A Dictionary of Tar Heel Places, (Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press), August 1984.

idinfo.useconst: Acknowledgement of products derived from this data set should cite the following: The source of this GIS data layer for Public Water Supply Sources is the North Carolina Corporate Geographic Database. Earlier versions of this dataset may exist. The user must be sure to use the appropriate data set for the time period of interest. While efforts have been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the state of the art, CGIA cannot assume liability for any damages or misrepresentation caused by any inaccuracies in the data or as a result of changes to the data caused by system transfers.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.2.3552

dataqual.logic: Built and maintained using Esri's ArcGIS software.
dataqual.complete: These data represent the locations of public water supply water sources.

citeinfo.title: Public Water Supply Wells and Intakes

srctime.srccurr: Original release date and update date,

srcinfo.srccitea: Public Water Supply Wells and Intakes
srcinfo.srccontr: Locations of sites and facility names supplied by Public Water Supply Section

procstep.procdesc: PWSS regions' GPS rover units data were transferred to a DWR server. Well locations were calculated by using Pathfinder software and base station files. The data were then converted to tabular text form so they could be imported into ArcGIS software for visual inspection purpose. The data were reviewed and necessary corrections made.

cntorgp.cntorg: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

cntinfo.cntinst: Preferred contact is by email or telephone.

enttyp.enttypd: Active Public Water Supply Sources are ground water and surface water sources for community (CWS), non-transient non-community (NTNC) and transient non-community (TNC) water systems.
enttyp.enttypds: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

attr.attrdef: Water Supply Watershed Classification for Surface Water
attr.attrdefs: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

edom.edomvd: Waters used as sources of potable water where a more protective WS-I or II classification is not feasible. These waters are also protected for Class C uses. WS-III waters are generally in low to moderately developed watersheds. General discharge permits only are allowed near the water supply intake whereas domestic and nonprocess industrial discharges are allowed in the rest of the water supply watershed.
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ-Division of Water Quality

edom.edomvd: Waters used as sources of potable water where a WS-I, II or III classification is not feasible. These waters are also protected for Class C uses. WS-IV waters are generally in moderately to highly developed watersheds or Protected Areas, and involve no categorical restrictions on discharges.
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ-Division of Water Quality

edom.edomvd: Waters used as sources of potable water where a WS-I classification is not feasible. These waters are also protected for Class C uses. WS-II waters are generally in predominantly undeveloped watersheds and only general permits for discharges are allowed. All WS-II waters are HQW by definition.
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ-Division of Water Quality

edom.edomvd: Waters protected as water supplies which are generally upstream and draining to Class WS-IV waters or waters used by industry to supply their employees with drinking water or as waters formerly used as water supply. These waters are also protected for Class C uses. WS-V has no categorical restrictions on watershed development or wastewater discharges unlike other WS classifications and local governments are not required to adopt watershed protection ordinances.
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ-Division of Water Quality

edom.edomvd: Waters used as sources of water supply for drinking, culinary, or food processing purposes for those users desiring maximum protection for their water supplies. These waters are also protected for Class C uses. WS-I waters are those within natural and undeveloped watersheds in public ownership with no permitted point source (wastewater) discharges. All WS-I waters are HQW by definition.
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ-Division of Water Quality

attr.attrdef: Number of connections to distribution system

attrdomv.udom: Connection values vary in number.

attr.attrdefs: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

edom.edomvd: An adjacent water system is a type of community water system that has two or more systems that are adjacent and are owned or operated by the same supplier of water, and together serve 15 or more connections or 25 or more persons. Examples of adjacent water systems are two mobile home parks that together meet the community water system definition.
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

edom.edomvd: A non-community water system that does not regularly serve 25 of the same persons over six months per year.
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

edom.edomvd: A community water system serves 15 or more service connections or regularly serves at least 25 year-round residents
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

edom.edomvd: A public water system that is not a community water system and regularly serves 25 of the same persons for at least 6 months a year.
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

edom.edomvd: A campground water system is a type of community water system that serves 15 or more connections and is not serving 25 or more of the same persons more than 6 months per year. In addition to campgrounds these water systems include travel trailer parks, and marinas.
edom.edomvds: NC DEQ, Division of Water Resources, Public Water Supply Section

overview.eaover: The attributes were supplied by the Public Water Supply Section of the Division of Water Resources relating to system type, source and system name, size, location, population served, responsible party and owner information, and contact information.

cntorgp.cntorg: NC Center for Geographic Information and Analysis

distinfo.distliab: NCCGIA is charged with the development and maintenance of NC OneMap and, in cooperation with other mapping organizations, is committed to offering its users accurate, useful, and current information. Although every effort has been made to ensure the accuracy of information, errors and conditions originating from physical sources used to develop this dataset may be reflected in the data supplied. The user must be aware of possible conditions and bear responsibility for the appropriate use of the information with respect to possible errors, original map scale, collection methodology, currency of data, and other conditions specific to certain data. NCCGIA does not support secondary distribution of this dataset without its current, compliant metadata record. The use of trade names or commercial products does not constitute their endorsement by NCCGIA or North Carolina State Government.

stdorder.fees: None. Download from http://www.nconemap.gov is free of charge.

cntorgp.cntorg: North Carolina Center for Geographic Information and Analysis

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata
metainfo.metuc: This metadata file is to accompany the dataset. NCCGIA does not support secondary distribution of this dataset without its current, compliant metadata record. If the dataset described in this metadata record was received from anyone besides NCCGIA, this metadata and the dataset it describes may contain discrepancies.
